data.text: EISENBEISZ FAMILY GENEALOGY 30-Dec-06 Compiled by: Clyde T. Eisenbeis Co-Compiled by: Albert Eisenbeisz of Germany, Dennis Eisenbeis of California, and Henri Eisenbeis of France ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Copyright 1982-2006 by Clyde T. Eisenbeis (a:3.1.5.3.7-4.8.2.1.3-7.1) Any portion of this document may be copied or reproduced with proper attribution without permission from the author unless designated otherwise. Proper attribution means that the copyright notice / date / author and this statement must always be part of the copied sections even if only portions of the document are used. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Contacts (current phone numbers, addresses, email addresses, related web sites): www.geocities.com/eisenbeiszz ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- GENEALOGY MAIN TREE & BRANCHES INFORMATION Not all of the Eisenbeisz families have been tied into one tree. To help ease the potential confusion with the different branches, two main trees with the code letters a: and b: have been established. These two main trees will be combined when the relationship between the two has been established. Additional branches which have not yet been tied to these main trees are labeled with the letters c: ... z:. When these branches are connected to one of the main trees, they will receive an a: or b: number. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ADDITIONS & CORRECTIONS: The genealogical section is still quite incomplete and may have errors. It is hoped that descendents from the different branches will continue the research in an attempt to fix the errors and to tie all of the families together into one tree. To help distribute the work load, it is requested that all information be entered electronically in the correct format and emailed to Clyde Eisenbeis. Contact Clyde for the correct format / current procedure (the procedures continue to evolve as technology changes). ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- GENEALOGY NUMBERING SYSTEM There can be considerable confusion with so many families. To ease the confusion, a numbering system is used throughout the entire document. The leading digits indicate the parent's number, and the last digit indicates the placement in the family (i.e. a:3.2 is the second child of the a:3 parents). ---- # a: Father > a:1 First Child > a:2 Second Child => > a:3 Third Child => > a:4 Fourth Child ---- # a:2 Second Child > a:2.1 First Child of a:2 > a:2.2 Second Child of a:2 => > a:2.3 Third Child of a:2 ---- # a:2.2 Second Child of a:2 > a:2.2.1 First Child of a:2.2 ---- # a:3 Third Child > a:3.1 First Child of a:3 > a:3.2 Second Child of a:3 ---- Note that a '-' is used instead of a '.' after every fifth character to help distinguish the differences between long strings of numbers ... for example, a:3.1.5.3.7-4.8.2.1.3-7.1 CLYDE THOMAS EISENBEIS. This number indicates that I am the oldest child, my father was the seventh child, my grandfather was the third child, my greatgrandfather was the oldest child, etc. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- GENEALOGY SYMBOLS (ZEICHEN) * Born (Geboren) + Died (Gestorben) ~ Baptized (Taufe) oo Married, Date (symbol of wedding rings) (Eheschlieszung, Datum) oo2 Married second time (Zweite Eheschlieszung) o/o Divorced d/o Daughter of s/o Son of => More information in a following section (Mehr information im folgend teil) The names after the husband and wife are the children A name enclosed by parenthesis indicates a nickname ... JOHANN (HANS) EISENBEISZ ... nickname is HANS. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Compiled by: .................... a: EISENBEISZ Clyde T. Pfarrer Strobel Sippenatlas Glatten 72293 Glatten/Freudenstadt Germany .................... Early Eisenbeisz names are in section aa. It is unknown how these individuals are related to each other. It is important to note that Eliasbrunn (old name Ehabrunn), Thierbach, Ruppersdorf, Gahma (Gamen), Friesau, Altengesees (Altengesass), Payreut (Bayreuth), Neunbeutha (Neunbeuta), and Lobenstein are all very close to each other. This is from where the b: and y: families and quite possibly the k: families originate. It is quite likely the a: family also originates from this area, but moved to the Freudenstad area. The following information (aa) is from a variety of sources including church records, history books, and tax listings.
